page.title: 03MONSAL DALE
page.content: {Monsal Dale }is sometimes called the Queen of the Derbyshire Dales. The River Wye flows through the dale which is famous for its wild flowers and the wild orchids. The Dale is well known for the river birds which gather there. Coots, ducks, dippers and Kingfishers are commonly seen. The Dale is crossed by the Monsal Viaduct which carried the Midland Railway between Matlock and Buxton. The Viaduct is 40 metres high, 100 metres long and has five arches. The railway entered the Dale after passing through the 540 metre long Headstone Tunnel. The coming of the railway caused great controversy when it opened, but the line closed in the 1960's and the track bed forms the Monsal Trail which is now used by walkers and cyclists.
